Lupus-like Syndromes induced by certain medications

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various organs and tissues of the body, causing a wide range of symptoms including joint inflammation (synovitis), cognitive changes or delirium, autoimmune hemolysis, proteinuria due to kidney involvement (lupus nephritis), and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While predominantly known for causing joint inflammation and damage, in severe cases, it can lead to systemic manifestations such as leukopenia and, less commonly, proteinuria. Autoimmune hemolysis and delirium are not typical but could be related in the context of severe systemic involvement or complications.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD combines features of multiple autoimmune diseases - lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Patients may exhibit synovitis, hemolytic anemia, leukopenia, and proteinuria among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects the exocrine glands but can have systemic manifestations. While synovitis and leukopenia are more commonly associated, proteinuria and autoimmune hemolysis can occur, especially in severe cases. Delirium would be less typical but not out of the realm of possibility in severe systemic disease or complications.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: This encompasses a group of disorders that cause blood vessel inflammation, damaging organs and tissues. Depending on the specific type, symptoms can include skin, kidney (proteinuria), nervous system (delirium), and blood manifestations (leukopenia and hemolytic anemia).

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can result in symptoms like leukopenia, hemolytic anemia, and less commonly, proteinuria. Synovitis and delirium are not typical symptoms but could be seen in severe or complicated cases.

diagnoses.name: Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)
diagnoses.rationale: HLH is an aggressive and life-threatening syndrome of excessive immune activation. Symptoms can include hemophagocytosis leading to hemolytic anemia, leukopenia, delirium due to central nervous system involvement, and proteinuria as part of organ dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
diagnoses.rationale: PNH is a rare, acquired, life-threatening disease of the blood characterized by destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis), bone marrow failure (which can cause leukopenia), and thrombosis. Proteinuria can occur as a result of kidney damage from hemolysis. Delirium and synovitis are not standard symptoms but could be linked to complications.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder characterized by the body mistakenly producing antibodies against certain normal proteins in the blood, leading to blood clots. It can feature hemolytic anemia, leukopenia (rare), and in advanced kidney involvement, proteinuria. Synovitis and delirium are not direct symptoms but could be present due to complications.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia, and in some cases, leukopenia. While synovitis, delirium, and proteinuria are not common manifestations, the broad autoimmune activity could potentially affect various body systems.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (and other primary psychotic disorders, considered if other causes are ruled out)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can present with pleural effusion, pericarditis, and fever. Neurologic involvement can lead to seizures. Skin manifestations can result in atrophic scarring.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily affecting joints, RA can also cause pleural effusions and pericarditis. Fever can occur during flare-ups. Rheumatoid nodules might lead to scarring.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Tuberculosis can cause pleural effusions, pericarditis, and fever. CNS involvement can lead to seizures, and TB can cause scarring in affected tissues.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: Similar to SLE but may have more pronounced skin involvement leading to atrophic scarring. Also causes serositis (pleural effusion, pericarditis) and can have neurologic involvement including seizures.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause pleural effusion and acute pericarditis. Neurosarcoidosis can lead to seizures. Fever can be present. Skin involvement can cause atrophic scarring.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.reasoning: Viral infections can cause acute pericarditis, pleural effusion, and fever. Seizures might occur if the virus affects the CNS. Atrophic scarring is less directly related but can occur from other effects of severe illness.

diagnoses.name: Cancer with Metastasis
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain cancers can metastasize to the pleura or pericardium, causing effusions. Fever and seizures may be related to systemic effects or metastases to the brain. Atrophic scarring can occur after radiation or chemotherapy.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Endocarditis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to fever and acute pericarditis as part of its systemic effects. Septic emboli can cause seizures. Not directly related to atrophic scarring.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This disease often combines features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis and can cause pleural effusions, pericarditis, seizures, fever, and skin changes that might lead to atrophic scarring.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: A rare multisystem inflammatory disorder that can cause fever, pericarditis, and pleural effusions. Neurological involvement can lead to seizures. Skin lesions can heal with atrophic scarring.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Squamous Cell Carcinoma (in the context of leukoplakia)

diagnoses.name: Otitis Externa
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the outer ear and ear canal, often associated with infection.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A common, chronic, and long-lasting disorder in which a person has uncontrollable, reoccurring thoughts (obsessions) and behaviors (compulsions) that he or she feels the urge to repeat over and over.

diagnoses.name: Dry Eye Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when your tears aren't able to provide adequate lubrication for your eyes. This can cause difficulty focusing vision.

diagnoses.name: Xerosis
diagnoses.description: A medical condition characterized by excessively dry skin.

diagnoses.name: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A red, itchy rash caused by direct contact with a substance or an allergic reaction to it. It might be pertinent if the otitis externa is being caused by an allergic response.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, which can lead to difficulty focusing vision and xerosis.

diagnoses.name: Eczema (Atopic Dermatitis)
diagnoses.description: A condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age. Eczema may cause skin changes that could also affect the ear canal (contributing to otitis externa) and lead to dry skin (xerosis).

diagnoses.name: Autism Spectrum Disorder
diagnoses.description: Although not directly related to the symptoms provided, individuals with this disorder can exhibit repetitive behaviors which might be misunderstood as obsessive-compulsive behaviors.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: Anxiety might exacerbate or contribute to obsessive-compulsive behaviors and perhaps make focusing vision more difficult due to increased tension.

diagnoses.name: Blepharitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the eyelids that can cause symptoms of eye dryness and potential difficulty focusing vision, as well as contributing to discomfort around the eyes.

diagnoses: Oral Infections (e.g., dental abscesses, periodontal disease)
Medication Side Effects (certain medications can lead to hyperglycemia, leukocytosis, and other symptoms)
Neurological Conditions (that could explain blepharospasm and attention deficits)
Psychological Conditions (stress or anxiety disorders inducing somatic symptoms)

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, potentially causing memory problems and episodic weakness among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that affects how the body processes blood glucose, potentially causing glycemic lability and, in advanced cases, peripheral neuropathy that might manifest as memory problems.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A deficiency in B12 can lead to various neurological issues, including memory problems, weakness, and potentially contribute to the development of leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include memory problems and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss, often associated with tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. It can lead to a buildup of toxins and impurities in the blood, which can cause memory problems and glycemic lability.

diagnoses.name: Oral Lichen Planus
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition affecting mucous membranes inside the mouth, potentially leading to leukoplakia. It doesn't directly relate to the other symptoms but could be part of a broader symptom complex.

diagnoses.name: Neurosyphilis
diagnoses.description: A late-stage syphilis infection that affects the brain and nervous system, potentially causing memory problems, weakness, and other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Alzheimer's Disease
diagnoses.description: A progressive neurological disorder that causes the brain to shrink (atrophy) and brain cells to die, leading to severe memory loss among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Depending upon its location, a brain tumor could cause a range of symptoms including memory problems, weakness, and possibly tinnitus if it affects certain areas.

diagnoses.name: Periodontitis
diagnoses.description: An advanced stage of periodontal disease characterized by gum inflammation and the destruction of bone and tissue around the teeth.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea, Obstructive
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by repeated episodes of upper airway obstruction during sleep, leading to reduced or paused breathing.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after exposure to a certain allergen, which can include hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: Though primarily associated with long-term smoking, COPD can share overlapping symptoms with obstructive sleep apnea, including difficulties in breathing.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus, Type 2
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that affects the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose). There's a known association between periodontal disease and type 2 diabetes.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, a whistling sound (wheezing) when you breathe out and shortness of breath.

diagnoses.name: Cardiovascular Disease
diagnoses.description: A class of diseases that involve the heart or blood vessels. Periodontal disease is a risk factor for cardiovascular disease.

diagnoses.name: Hemangioma
diagnoses.description: A type of benign (non-cancerous) tumor made up of blood vessels, sometimes referred to as angiomata in plural form.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation, which can cause bleeding and lead to various complications, including arteriovenous malformations.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. There is an association between periodontal disease and rheumatoid arthritis.

diagnoses: Secondary Immunodeficiency due to Chronic Conditions or Medications

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Infectious diseases (e.g., bacterial, viral, parasitic infections)
Primary insomnia due to a medical condition, specifically restless legs syndrome
Dental conditions (e.g., tooth decay, gum disease, or jaw pain)
Autoimmune Disorders (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, SLE)
Asthma (reactive airway disease, in context with other symptoms)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) - Crohn's Disease/Ulcerative Colitis
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) exacerbation with allergic reaction
Bacterial Infections such as E. coli or Salmonella
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Neurodegenerative Disorders (e.g., Alzheimer's Disease, Parkinson's Disease)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Chronic Hepatitis B or C infection
